doc.title: 2Q25 Key Takeaways
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/Williams-Sonoma Inc. 2Q25 Key TakeawaysWilliams-Sonoma Inc. 2Q25 Key Takeaways_2025-08-28

passages.text: Williams- Sonoma, Inc.

Q2 sales were about in line with our recently revised estimates, but well ahead on the bottom line. We would not extrapolate all of that but do believe the company is executing well and is better positioned to navigate more tariff volatility ahead. No change to full- year estimates.

Key message: We come away from Q2 relatively positive on WSM's positive and steadier sales performance, the broad momentum across its brands and various initiatives, and its ability to digest the meaningful tariff increase since Q1 while maintaining its prior margin targets for the year. Q2 GM upside was impressive but also included a timing mismatch (higher retail prices vs. pre- tariff inventory) that should not be fully extrapolated; we expect that will start to reverse in Q3 and reverse further in Q4, with higher costs in theory wrapping into FY26. WSM may have some offsets but additional changes to tariffs are looming, likely creating further uncertainty. As such, our full- year estimates are unchanged, and we remain EW as we balance strong execution and better than average financial visibility within this group, while monitoring for evidence that EPS can grow more meaningfully in FY26.

Top line better than Bloomberg consensus about in line with market expectations, with comps \(+3.7\%\) . This included positive comps across all brands, channels, and in both furniture and non- furniture.
1. Our sense is that trends were relatively consistent throughout the period vs. volatility we have seen with some other players.

2. Price increases did accelerate in Q2 although the company remains surgical in its approach. Our own work has suggested a \(\sim 200\) bps impact (baseline, before considering mix). Mix could have skewed the net benefit on comps lower (e.g., heavy back-to-school mix in July). We believe the impact from pricing could accelerate in 2H. Elasticity overall seems low but does vary at the product level.

3. Looking ahead, WSM suggested QTD trends consistent with Q2. FY sales guidance was raised to \(+0.50\% - + 3.5\%\) (from \(-1.5\% - 1.5\%\) ) and comps guidance raised to \(+2.0\% - + 5.0\%\) (from \(0.0\% - 3.0\%\) ). This implies 2H 1-6%, with mid point of 3.5%, similar to the current run-rate.

4. Gross margin came in better than expected at \(47.1\%\) vs our \(45.1\%\) and consensus \(44.6\%\) . Merch margins were up 190 bps, largely due to higher retail prices mismatched with pre- tariff inventory; however, we would not extrapolate this benefit as we expect tariff headwinds will increase in Q3 and again in Q4. We believe guidance still embeds gross margin down for the full year, which we assume will be weighted more heavily towards Q4.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 4. Completed: 28- Aug- 25, 03:40 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 09:45 GMT Restricted - External
U.S. Broadlines, Hardlines & NEUTRAL Food Retail
Price Target USD 180.00 Unchanged
Price (27- Aug- 25) USD 192.17 Potential Upside/Downside - 6.3% Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

Market Cap (USD mn) 23636 Shares Outstanding (mn) 123.00 Free Float (%) 98.78 52 Wk Avg Daily Volume (mn) 1.9 Dividend Yield (%) 1.37 Return on Equity TTM (%) 51.75 Current BVPS (USD) 17.65 Source: Bloomberg
Price Performance Exchange- NYSE 52 Week range USD 219.98- 125.33
Source: IDC Link to Barclays Live for interactive charting

5. Operating margin came in better as well, at 17.9% vs consensus est. 15.6% and our 15.9%. SG&A rate declined 20 bps y/y driven by the stronger top line, advertising 80 bps lower, general expenses 40 bps lower, partially offset by 100 bps of higher incentive comp (caught up for the year, ex-further EPS beats).

6. Management has reiterated operating margin guidance for the FY at 17.4%-17.8%, with top-line growth offsetting incremental tariffs. This implies an operating margin of 17.8% in 2H, which would be -180 bps y/y, reflecting tariffs, and lapping the extra week, which negatively impacts Q4 by around 70 bps.

7. Since May, the company's tariff rate has doubled from 14% to 28%, and broader furniture tariffs are expected. We expect tariff impacts to accelerate throughout the back half and into 26, with more price increases likely needed.
8. We believe the company is well positioned to address incremental tariffs, with furniture imports only comprising 35% of the total business, balanced by the textile, decor, and culinary assortment.

9. Inventory accelerated up +17.7% in 2Q as management continued to pull forward receipts ahead of assumed tariff rate increases. Both retail and e-commerce comps benefited from higher in-stocks as a result.
10. We expect AI to drive continued cost efficiencies across the supply chain, customer service operations, and internal operations.

11. Model changes: We raise FY25E comps to 3.5% from 3.0%, based on the updated guidance. We raise FY25EGM to 45.7% from 45.5% and raise operating margin to 18.0% from 17.5%. We maintain FY25E EPS at \$8.61, with lower flow-through based on incremental tariffs and a higher tax rate. We lower FY26E GM to 45.1% from 45.8%, and maintain FY26E EPS of \$8.97.
WSM:Quarterly and Annual EPS (USD)
Consensus numbers are from Bloomberg received on 27-Aug-2025; 12:50 GMT Source: Barclays Research

Unless otherwise indicated, prices are sourced from Bloomberg and reflect the closing price in the relevant trading market, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.

P: A partner, director or officer of Barclays Capital Canada Inc. has, during the preceding 12 months, provided services to the subject company for remuneration, other than normal course investment advisory or trade execution services.
R: Barclays Capital Canada Inc. has received compensation for investment banking services from this issuer in the past 12 months.
S: This issuer is a Corporate Broker to Barclays PLC.
U: The equity securities of this Canadian issuer include subordinate voting restricted shares.
V: The equity securities of this Canadian issuer include non- voting restricted shares.
Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.
Below is the list of companies that constitute the "industry coverage universe":

On 27-Aug- 2022, prior to any intra- day change that may have been published, the rating for this security was Overweight, and the adjusted price target was 96.00.
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
\*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.
Valuation Methodology: Our \(\) 180\$ price target is based on 13x our FY26E EBITDA estimate of \(\) 1.6B\(, which is above the stock's 5 - year average.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Risk to upside include stronger macro and pricing power, while risks to downside would be a further slowdown in housing and challenges passing through higher prices along with increasing competition from more promotional channels requiring WSM to return to discounting.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate-friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated.
